text: also, just noticed <@U0548MM6B>’s flair
:smile:
dat 1337 flair
:smile:
so guys
today’s the day I make my stand

1) Material Design discussion
2) API discussion
3) General Android direction discussion
puts on cheerleader outfit. GOOO E-D-D-I-E
are they happy with the MVP?
1 & 2 are pretty much locked in, I think
and yeah, MVP is serving its purpose

for #3 there are a few things I want to suggest:
1. Consider Kotlin, mainly for productivity as well as null-safety, as the majority of crashes during development were NullPointerExceptions (it also hit 1.0 Beta today, so I can claim that the language itself is stable)
2. Rx all the things
3. Look into Clean architecture
4. At the very least, throw out the current architecture and replace it with a single Activity and make sure to separate concerns
my CEO wants to move fast, and I think all of those things would help us do that

I’m pretty sure they’ll be reaaal vary of switching to kotlin - hiring for kotlin will be hard if you leave and the other dev will have low productivity at first. But other things, yeah, totes for it.
well, I can even help our current engineer get up to speed
but Kotlin itself is pretty straightforward, I think
I learned it in a day
well yeah, but you have loads more xp points in java then she has
so that translates easily
hah
that’s not something I care to admit, lol
:smile:
I’ve always preferred C to Java
mainly I just want to get rid of all the spaghetti code that we currently call an app
it’s not horrible, but it’s not going to help our “move fast” goal
yeah, I understand what you mean, trying to do the same thing here
<@U053LEHJN>: is there no CTO to take care of those discussions?
<@U0548MM6B>: no, CEO is an engineer so he assumes the CTO role as well
I’m not 100% behind the single activity idea
in my experience at some point they start accumulating too many external apis
from all the permission, camera, oauth, context etc
I didn’t say stick everything in that activity :wink:
but if you keep everything in fragments, you can have only one activity :simple_smile:
An Activity should just be an adapter that connects your app to the Android framework
or that mortar/flow thingy?
or that yea
a fragment cannot receive a callback from webpage, or launch from a push notification <@U0548MM6B>
the app I wrote in the first half of the year was a single Activity, then I wrote my own presentation layer that just used views and navigation was handled by a URL router I wrote
<@U0B8R3VV4>: emphasis on the URL router
I’ve done that and it was beautiful
everything in my app had a URL
yeah
interesting
it was amazing
got it on github anywhere?
<@U053PPGDC>: the app itself was a private contract
ok
ooh what what that sounds coolish
I have v2 of the router in a private GitHub repo
incomplete from a redesign
I can post this though:
<@U053LEHJN|eddie.ringle> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/eddie.ringle/F0DLTP3H7/Untitled.txt|Untitled>

file.name: Untitled.txt
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
getRouter().route("/about")
                .presentIn<AboutPresenter>(contentView!!, R.id.p_about)
        getRouter().route("/dashboard")
                .presentIn<DashboardPresenter>(contentView!!, R.id.p_dashboard)
        getRouter().route("/map")

text: that’s the code in the single Activity that hooked all the urls up to my presentation system
which is what Google intended with content providers, but failed miserably
yup
I assume contentView is the root view in which you inflate the presenters?
right
v2 is much nicer
uses Kotlin’s DSL features a bit better
but like I said, it’s still incomplete :stuck_out_tongue:
oh so *Presenter is a  view that you bind to  a presenter or a controller?
Yeah. Presenters are really just FrameLayouts with some special lifecycle stuff
really, that should be decoupled even more though
yeah confused me a bit cuz they’re called presenters so was not sure if it’s logic or view
it’s not a Presenter in the MVP sense (I wrote this before MVP became a craze)
it’s just what I called them
We did something like that but with fragments. Kinda. In a really shitty way tho :D
v1 (above) didn’t use Fragments at all
just a Router that wrapped via a ContextWrapper
v2 actually uses a single retained Fragment
so all the lifecycle stuff and configuration state handling can be contained there
which is the ideal use of Fragments IMO
they shouldn’t be used for managing Views
man I miss writing in Kotlin :anguished:
man I wish I could write kotlin on the job :disappointed:
I’m going to try and push for it again today
CEO said wait until after MVP
so that’s what I did :stuck_out_tongue:
tell us how did the battle go :smile:
I’m writing up a doc with all my ideas now so I can share it
We’re having a meeting this afternoon to talk about post-MVP direction
and I also have meetings to discuss API evolution and Material Design, respectively
so today will be a long day

text: oh that fits this old POS were maintaining right this very moment to the core.
<@U0DM5TP6D|tim> has joined the channel

lol so today is the last day for one of the guys here. And our boss said he was going to pay for lunch for us all to go to lunch since its his last day. And asked where we wanted to go. So almost all at once 3 people said Ruths Chris. It got vetoed.
since it’s like $100/person
#shouldnthaveasked
HOLY
MOLY
I would have said ruth chris too.. place is bomb
so this is the document I presented at the meeting just now: <https://gist.github.com/EddieRingle/f200d3277d4b799bc988>
With some of the ideas I had to move our app forward
we didn’t even get past discussing #1
(said document was a bit rushed and I was literally working on it as our meeting started, so not everything is as clear as I’d like it to be)
I’m trying to suggest moving to a CLEAN architecture variant
i think material should have been 1)
<@U055GGAHS>: Material has its own meeting later today, that’s all good
so does API stuff
1, 2, & 5 are the big ones I wanted to discuss
as for kotlin.. i guess lol
i wouldn’t be against it I would just probably argue we already have problems no need to add more
well, in the discussion for #1, other engineer was saying our multiple activity, multiple fragment approach is the most stable
and the crashes are stuff like NullPointerExceptions and the like
so I had ammo for the Kotlin discussion, as Kotlin doesn’t have null pointer crashes (normally), but we never got to it :disappointed:
wouldnt agree multiple activities is safer
that’s like saying doing X is safer
its probably not true and an opinion

the point I was trying to get across was, modularize the app so that stuff like Activity and Fragment are just thin connecting components that bridge our app’s views and logic to the Android framework
having 1 activity and making everything you can a fragment makes testing easier which is an actual argument
<@U055GGAHS>: ive never been to ruths chris
:disappointed:
sorry <@U0BF5DD8T>
<@U055GGAHS>: CEO had to end the meeting since he had another one to go to and now we have to do this again
later
at one point he even said “okay, who wants to own all the architecture-related stuff, so if you’re wrong I know who to blame?"
well, i just finished paying off my fiancees wedding ring. So i may take her there. i dunno. maybe its time. lol
well, both of us wanted to own it
so the threat of responsibility didn’t work, lol
damn
another argument against multiple activities is animation is a bitch
<@U055GGAHS>: CEO’s motto is “Get Shit Done”, wouldn’t you agree that modularizing the app in such a way would enable more momentum going forward?
though animating items between fragments is also a real bitch
and yeah, I brought up transitions too
<@U055GGAHS>: I wouldn’t use Fragments for Views, but that’s yet another discussion (series?)

that’s it

the less Android is doing for your app, the better

but man I’d think someone would finally get hired
so I talked with the lead iOS engineer
specifically about my proposals
He said he was just trying to compile objective information about each
I think I sold my ideas pretty well, heh

When we got to Kotlin, I asked him what moving to Swift was like. I also said I’d be fine with waiting a bit (which he said they’d likely end up doing) and just wanted to make them aware of the advantages of the language. He ended up saying it’s probable that they’d be moving that way in the future, but not right away.
For Rx I explained it as one-part functional pipeline, other-part suped-up, tightly-coupled event bus
And I think I convinced him on using a single Activity, since he asked if we’d be losing anything by dropping multiple activities and I couldn’t think of any downsides.
and even drew parallels to iOS development where all you have to do to switch screens is swap the views out

so i may expose myself as a total nub here, but why single activity/multiple fragments? I’ve done apps both ways, single activity/n fragments, and I’ve done 1 activity-1 fragment, and its always seemed to be the best way to do things, regardless of what Google says.

<@U0A0S0WG0>: In our case, my primary argument is that going between Activities requires throwing away the existing Window and all its Views, starting the new Activity (along with its dependencies), and reconstructing a new Window with new Views
i never really saw the difference either way except one activity is less code than multiple activities
<@U053LEHJN>: so you have at least him on your side, since he’s lead, that’s good
Whereas with a single Activity you just have to swap Views out, which also helps with animations and transitions
<@U0548MM6B>: well, I should say he was the original iOS developer
<@U053LEHJN>: so what? Unless your working on shit terrible phones in Africa and India, thats basically a free operation
<@U0548MM6B>: the new iOS developer worked at Apple for a time, so I’m not sure who’s more senior there, heh
<@U0A0S0WG0>: that, and multiple Activities introduces the hassle of dealing with Intents and passing arguments and crap
it’s just needless overhead
isn’t that waaaaay less overhead than trying to needlessly manage a whole bunch of state for a bunch of fragments?

<@U0A0S0WG0>: it’s kinda iffy, since activities and fragment both have fragile lifecycle and in 1 act w 1 frag, you’re basically wrapping view+logic inside a fragment inside view+logic of the activity, so you have to manage bunch of activities and bunch of fragments
and if you use 1 activity and multiple fragments
you just keep the activity as a container
hmm
see, i see it the other way around
you keep all your view shit out of your activity
<@U053LEHJN>: apple dev? ooh nice nice
put it in your fragment, and all your actual business logic in your activity
and then you have like nothing to deal with
but maybe i’m just really missing the ball on this one
oh no, I put business logic inside presenters, never inside activities or fragments
hmm
but also, why have multiple activites if your views aren’t inside your activities?

yeah, my MVP rule is no *.android.* can go inside the presenter
it’s always in the View implementation
and that is mostly fragments and activities, but I’m all for 1 activity multiple fragments
man, seriously, someone’s going to need to explain this to me in more detail
I still use multiples, but that is more from obligation currently
because we have an app that was outsourced before I started
and its for a Fortune 500 company
the whole thing is one activity, n fragments
and its a total cluster fuck
and i just got done with an app for a client, one activity, one fragment
and its clean as shit
depends, what is inside that activity?
literally everything?
oh then that’s fucked

<@U0548MM6B>: how big or how small are your fragments? I have cases where I have an activity-level widget with lifecycle and associated websocket, while at the same time swapping around fragments in the main container
ok….. but where else is it going to go?
that stuff grows fast in code
I don’t like fragments, but I’d rather control them inside of one activity
you are blowin my mind right now
im so confused
inside the fragment, the presenter, the interactor?
why would you put logic inside your fragment that isn’t view related?
yes, anywhere, but when your app grows beyond 30+ screens, how big is that main presenter?
I don’t, I put it in the presenter :smile:
you have to split it into interactors I guess
it’s not a main presenter, every logical unit has it’s own presenter
where I split it into activities + interactors
ok
so
can someone point me to a basic sample app that demonstrates this?
because its just not making sense
let’s say you have a idk UserListFragment and MovieGridFragment and a idk SingerListFragment. You then have a UserListPresenter, MovieGridPresenter, SingerListPresenter
How about you PM all of us so we can learn?
It’s not public since it’s PM
/giphy do it
lol wtf
sell the secrets :stuck_out_tongue:
people have meme’d the hell outta that clip
basically, how would you make instagram with multiple activities?
<@U0A0S0WG0>: yeah, if you use a single Activity, you CANNOT do what Google recommends and have an interface per Fragment and do all the coupling within that Activity
that would make things insane
yeah, thats what the guys we outsourced to did

i want to kill myself every time i have to touch it
